contentfulBlogPost.title: Test page Myths and facts about homelessness

description.en-US: Artist's drawing of homeless person with sign

content.value: To get into the myths of homelessness, we first need to define what homelessness is. According to the Library of Parliament, homeless is divided into three broad terms:
Absolute homelessness: This is a narrow term that includes people who live on the streets or in emergency shelters.

Hidden or concealed homelessness: This term falls in the middle of the continuum and includes people living without a place of their own. This could include a car, with family or a long-term institution.

Relative homelessness: This falls on the other end of the continuum and is a broad category covering those who live in a house but live in substandard shelters, or may be at risk of losing their house.
To fully comprehend the umbrella term that is
, it is best to think of it as a pyramid in which homelessness is the tip of the iceberg.
According to various organizations, for every homeless person visible on the street, there are four whose homelessness is concealed.
Around 250,000-300,000 Canadians suffer from homelessness every year, and almost 25,000-30,000 bear the consequences of homelessness on any given night.
Since a substantial part of our community is facing this problem, it is important we address some myths and make it our job to educate ourselves more on the issue.

content.value: The most prominent stereotype imposed on the homeless is that the majority of them abuse drugs and alcohol
. This, as a matter of fact, is entirely false as statistics show only about 20-40% of the homeless community has a substance abuse history/problem.
Oftentimes, substance abuse is more so a coping mechanism or response to homelessness as they are exposed to more dealers and users of the substance

. Another stereotype imposed on homeless people is them being criminals.  This mainly happens because most of the homeless’ daily activities are criminalized such as getting arrested for minor offences like trespassing, littering and loitering. The next big claim is that the homeless people chose this life because of their bad choices. We have all made mistakes at some point in our lives; however, the fall to homelessness comes more as a direct result of one losing their job, being a victim to an illness, experiencing an unfortunate accident, or falling into debt.

question.en-US: Between 2000-2019, the Canadian unemployment rate has hovered around 5-10%. According to CAMH, what is the unemployment rate among individuals afflicted with the most extreme mental illnesses?

content.value: We have all heard this one: “They just need to get a job”.

A good portion of homeless people are working, but they simply cannot afford to pay rent. Moreover, most of the job listings require a stable housing, address and proper clothing, which makes getting a job much harder for the homeless. Another stereotype is that the homeless choose to live in unsanitary conditions . When people are conditioned to living outside, they are automatically in a place where there is no daily disposal for bodily functions, no set place to dispose of trash, nor containers to store food.  The last myth we will be discussing is the notion that there are plenty of services and support for the homeless. While this stands true, it only works in the short-term, there are individuals seeking long-term solutions to get out of the cycle of homelessness. It is integral we shed light on the need for more affordable housing and the need to confront the rising criminalization of homelessness which inhibits this community from receiving the permanent shelter that they need.
